awd_titl_txt: HDR: DIRSE-IL: Collaborative Research: Harnessing data advances in systems biology to design a biological 3D printer: the synthetic coral
awd_abstract_narration:
Corals are important natural resources that are key to the ocean's vast biodiversity and provide economic, cultural, and scientific benefits. As a result of human activities, locally and globally, coral reefs are declining rapidly. The complexity of corals makes conserving and restoring reefs very challenging. Corals are made up of thousands of different organisms, including the animal host and the algae, bacteria, viruses, and fungi that coexist as a so-called holobiont. Thus, corals are more like cities than individual animals, as they provide factories, housing, restaurants, nurseries, and more for an entire ecosystem. This project brings together experts in computer science, materials science, and biology to harness the data revolution in biology with machine learning to study how corals grow and function, when viewed as if they were manufacturing sites in the ocean. The study will focus on three key coral capabilities: (1) they create calcium carbonate skeletons that provide 3D structures for diverse sea life to live in, (2) they can heal damage to their tissues, and, (3) they live with the other organisms in a process referred to as symbiosis. Through these remarkable abilities, corals can 'print' resources for themselves and hundreds of thousands of other species, just like a 3D printer. The goal of this project is to understand these processes well enough to control them in the lab. This project may allow finding new ways to help coral survival, by deciphering the reasons why certain conditions damage them and find ways of repairing them. Furthermore, by synthetically growing corals, new types of materials may be identified for manufacturing. This project offers an opportunity to educate a diverse scientific workforce and the public by creating and disseminating the outcomes of a convergent research environment and will train postdoctoral researchers, graduate, and undergraduate students. Results of this research will be made available to the broader scientific community through web interfaces, peer-reviewed publications and workshops/conferences and shared with the public through outreach activities online, at schools, and public aquariums.
				
Through convergence of three disciplines, computer science, material science and biology, this project will provide a data-driven framework and toolset to learn from, control, engineer, and manufacture a combined form of living material, the 'synthetic coral', thereby opening new avenues for material synthesis and manufacturing. The research methodology will offer new analytical approaches to identify and quantify the parameters that govern coral growth and foster innovative new tools for controlling their growth. To understand the key functions of coral biology of biomineralization, wound healing, and symbiosis, this research will : (1) harness and analyze large amounts of coral '-omics' data to decipher critical molecules and their interactions for the aforementioned key functions, (2) experimentally validate the resulting predictions in coral individuals and cell lines, (3) manipulate the material properties of the calcium carbonate structures of the coral individuals and cell lines, and (4) test the biological and physical interactions in a network model of the 'synthetic coral'. This project develops and integrates fundamental building blocks that are essential for  an integrated computational and experimental validation system. Specifically, using machine learning, diverse data will be harnessed to identify physical conditions (e.g., surface characteristics), environmental conditions (e.g., temperature, pH), and key biological constituents (e.g., small molecule ligands and proteins encoded in the DNA) that are correlated to key structural and functional properties of the coral holobiont. These predicted conditions and molecules will be verified experimentally by perturbing individual coral nodes in a network of a 3D printed array of intact corals or their constituent cells and measuring their effects on the network of interactions and resulting structures. The results from this prediction-validation cycle will then be transferred back as input to manufacture novel adaptive materials fully embracing the organic/inorganic interface. 

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Coral reefs are declining rapidly as a result of anthropogenic activities. There is an extreme urgency to assist corals in overcoming the impacts of pollution and global warming before the damage to these vital reef ecosystems is irreparable.  There is an opportunity to dramatically improve the way coral reefs are protected and restored through the development of novel approaches to understand and protect corals. 


The overarching goal of this project was to harness the large coral biology data by taking a data-driven manufacturing point of view in an effort to assist coral survival and improved health. To this end, the team consisting of researchers at Colorado School of Mines, Virginia Commonwealth University, University of Washington, University of Rhode Island and Tufts University provided a data-driven framework and toolset to learn from, control, engineer, and manufacture a combined form of living material, the ?synthetic coral?, thereby opening new avenues for coral reef rescue.

Intellectual Merit 

To achieve the overall goal of the project, the interdisciplinary team worked on four major aims: Aim-1: Data aim, Aim-2: Biology aim, Aim-3: Materials aim, and Aim-4: Network aim. The goal of Aim-1 was to predict the building blocks of the synthetic coral through (1) remote homology detection to assign unknown coral holobiont proteins to functions, (2) prediction of protein-protein and protein-ligand interactions and (3) creating a central 3D coral printer file format and repository for interoperability. The goal of Aim-2 was to experimentally validate the predictions from Aim-1 about key aspects of the synthetic coral: (1) establishing coral polyp and cell cultures, (2) biomineralization at polyp and cell levels, (3) manipulation of symbiotic relationship and (4) direct biomineralization via wound healing. The results of these fundamental objectives were then to be used in Aim-3 for tailored biomineralization and Aim-4 to study information flow across multiple units within the synthetic coral. The results of these objectives are published in 18 peer-reviewed papers. These papers have been co-authored by at least 2, usually more than 2 co-PI?s demonstrating the commitment to collaboration in the synthetic coral team. Computational pipelines and standards and experimental validation platforms have been established and shared across the 5 disparate sites. Knowledge transfer from research in human health and tissue engineering to corals has yielded novel, quantitative investigations of corals never carried out before. A new field of coral pharmacology has been founded. Groundbreaking new hypotheses regarding functions and dysfunctions in corals that may underlie their behavior have been proposed, opening new avenues of research never before pursued such as sensing by GPCR and aberrant insulin signaling as a potential cause for dysbiosis.

 

Broader Impacts

The project started as a new collaboration arising from an NSF ideas lab on harnessing the data revolution. The core partners involved 5 institutions, but the project has grown and expanded to a network involving over 40 participants. The diverse backgrounds (computer science, biology, chemistry, material science, toxicology, aerospace engineering and others) provided numerous opportunities of cross-education. For example, four labs previously not involved with coral research have been exposed to and embedded in the coral research field and community. Four conferences/workshops have been organized by the synthetic coral team to disseminate the concepts and findings to the respective disciplinary communities on the one hand, and the coral community on the other hand. Due to the distributed nature of the collaborators and subject (underocean corals) and the diverse disciplinary backgrounds involved demanded the development of novel collaboration tools, based on virtual reality. Finally, a community effort was conducted through an international art competition which explored the analogy between human and coral through art. The Tandem Human Coral competition attracted submissions from 126 artists which have been displayed in several art shows, as well as in conjunction with a major scientific conference and as a virtual reality gallery.

 


Last Modified: 10/21/2022
Modified by: Judith Klein

Image
  • The image depicts the goal of the synthetic coral project: harness the data revolution to gain a better understanding of coral biology and leverage it for material science applications.
    Synthetic coral project consortium members.
    Judith Klein
    Synthetic coral project
